Text:
`paste -d, "file 1" "file 2"`

-d is the delimiter ","

note that paste is the inverse of the 'cut' command, you may want to play with that as well.

`paste -d, "file 1" "file 2"` -d is the delimiter "," note that paste is the inverse of the 'cut' command, you may want to play with that as well. Output: 

Field A, Field B, Field C,Field D, Field E, Field F
1,2,3,4,5,6
,
aa,bb,cc,dd,ee,ff

`paste -d, "file 1" "file 2" | grep -Ev "^,$"` This will remove all the lines that are blank, if you don't want that say so. Output: 

Field A, Field B, Field C,Field D, Field E, Field F
1,2,3,4,5,6
aa,bb,cc,dd,ee,ff
below will result in "," on empty lines. `paste -d, "file 1" "file 2"` -d is the delimiter "," note that paste is the inverse of the 'cut' command, you may want to play with that as well. Output: 

Field A, Field B, Field C,Field D, Field E, Field F
1,2,3,4,5,6
,
aa,bb,cc,dd,ee,ff

This is what you want. `paste -d, "file 1" "file 2" | sed 's/^,$//g'` Output: 

Field A, Field B, Field C,Field D, Field E, Field F
1,2,3,4,5,6

aa,bb,cc,dd,ee,ff
similar command strings that are worth looking at follow: `paste -d, "file 1" "file 2" | grep -Ev "^,$"` This will remove all the lines that are blank, but you don't want that Output: 

Field A, Field B, Field C,Field D, Field E, Field F
1,2,3,4,5,6
aa,bb,cc,dd,ee,ff
below will result in "," on empty lines. `paste -d, "file 1" "file 2"` -d is the delimiter "," note that paste is the inverse of the 'cut' command, you may want to play with that as well. Output: 

Field A, Field B, Field C,Field D, Field E, Field F
1,2,3,4,5,6
,
aa,bb,cc,dd,ee,ff

This is what you want. `paste -d, "file 1" "file 2" | sed 's/^,$//g'` Output: 

Field A, Field B, Field C,Field D, Field E, Field F
1,2,3,4,5,6

aa,bb,cc,dd,ee,ff
note that paste is the inverse of the 'cut' command, you may want to play with that as well. similar command strings that are worth looking at follow: `paste -d, "file 1" "file 2" | grep -Ev "^,$"` This will remove all the lines that are blank, but you don't want that. Output: 

Field A, Field B, Field C,Field D, Field E, Field F
1,2,3,4,5,6
aa,bb,cc,dd,ee,ff

This: `paste -d, "file 1" "file 2" | sed 's/^,$//g' | sed 's/^,/,,,/g'` Will give: 

Field A, Field B, Field C,Field D, Field E, Field F
1,2,3,4,5,6

aa,bb,cc,dd,ee,ff
,,,o1,o2,o3
This: `paste -d, "file 1" "file 2" | sed 's/^,/,,,/g' | sed 's/,$/,,,/g'` Will give: 

Field A, Field B, Field C,Field D, Field E, Field F
1,2,3,4,5,6
,,,,,
aa,bb,cc,dd,ee,ff
,,,o1,o2,o3
This: `paste -d, "file 1" "file 2" | sed 's/^,$//g'` Will give: 

Field A, Field B, Field C,Field D, Field E, Field F
1,2,3,4,5,6

aa,bb,cc,dd,ee,ff
,o1,o2,o3

This: `paste -d, "file 1" "file 2" | sed -e 's/^,$//g;s/^,/,,,/g'` Will give: 

Field A, Field B, Field C,Field D, Field E, Field F
1,2,3,4,5,6

aa,bb,cc,dd,ee,ff
,,,o1,o2,o3
This: `paste -d, "file 1" "file 2" | sed -e 's/^,/,,,/g;s/,$/,,,/g'` Will give: 

Field A, Field B, Field C,Field D, Field E, Field F
1,2,3,4,5,6
,,,,,
aa,bb,cc,dd,ee,ff
,,,o1,o2,o3
This: `paste -d, "file 1" "file 2" | sed 's/^,$//g'` Will give: 

Field A, Field B, Field C,Field D, Field E, Field F
1,2,3,4,5,6

aa,bb,cc,dd,ee,ff
,o1,o2,o3
